在哈马斯袭击以色列后的一周，我写了一篇非常沮丧的文章，内容是西方左翼人士（其中许多人急于表达对哈马斯的声援）如何丧失了美国社会的大部分道德制高点。该帖子现已成为该博客历史上最受欢迎的帖子之一。但这让一些人感到困惑。谁是“左派”？当然是 DSA，但是 BLM 呢？或者伯尼·桑德斯或 AOC？拜登是“左派”吗？当这么多著名的民主党和进步领导人站出来谴责哈马斯时，我到底在谴责谁？

这是一个公平的问题。如果你不密切关注在线政治辩论（老实说，你为什么要关注？），“左派”这个词可能看起来与“进步”甚至“自由派”这个词没有什么不同。甚至一些关注这些辩论的人也不知道像我这样的作家到底在哪里划清界限。如果您要抱怨整个群体，那么明确该群体中的成员很重要。

事实上，对于谁是“左派”并没有官方定义——他们自己当然不会使用这个词。但自从 2016 年伯尼·桑德斯的运动在全国舞台上爆发以来，我直观地清楚地看到，他的许多最热心的支持者关心的是一系列不同的问题，以不同的方式谈论政治，并从不同的人那里获取信息。与大多数进步主义者相比，其来源有些不同。他们对民主党建制派深恶痛绝，总是谈论推翻民主党并接管该党。他们似乎更关心学生贷款和取消自付费用的医疗费用。他们经常反对新住房建设。他们更有可能称自己为“社会主义者”，并对乌戈·查韦斯怀有钦佩之情。他们似乎更加关注外交政策（尤其是在拜登在经济问题上抢了他们的风头之后）。他们经常称美国为“帝国”。

最重要的是，他们似乎比普通进步主义者更痴迷于巴勒斯坦。巴勒斯坦事业本质上并不是社会主义，而且还有很多其他民族也受到压迫，他们也应该拥有自己的国家。但在我眼中的“西方左派”中，巴勒斯坦问题在他们的事业万神殿中远远高于其他所有国家。这是他们与进步主义者最明显的区别之一。我一直不太明白为什么。

现在我想我开始更好地理解了。在一篇关于他为何退出 DSA 的帖子中，莫里斯·伊瑟曼 (Maurice Isserman) 解释说，巴勒斯坦已成为一个楔子问题，极端主义“进入者”用来排挤更温和的成员：

随着新的强硬派核心小组获得影响力，巴勒斯坦问题在 DSA 的内部政治文化中变得越来越重要……[以色列对巴勒斯坦人的镇压]并没有说明巴勒斯坦在 DSA 相当短的国际关切清单中所扮演的极其重要的角色，完全掩盖了对俄罗斯入侵乌克兰或库尔德穆斯林或中国维吾尔穆斯林等其他受压迫人民权利的关注。对巴勒斯坦的关心本身是完全合理的，也为 DSA 新的宗派领导层服务于其他目的，如果 DSA 的温和派不愿意在巴勒斯坦问题上采取最极端的立场，甚至包括否认，那么它就可以提供便利的大棒来打击 DSA 的温和派。以色列继续存在的权利……

早在 2017 年全国代表大会上，DSA 集会上就开始响起“从河流到海洋，巴勒斯坦将自由”的口号，对针对以色列的抵制、撤资和制裁（BDS）运动的支持成为组织内政治纯洁性的试金石。对于宗派主义者来说，抹黑那些未通过测试的民选民主社会主义者有助于使该组织更接近与民主党的理想决裂。

这很有意义。巴勒斯坦不仅仅是一场因美国与以色列结盟而被民主党建制派淡化的解放斗争；它也是一场解放斗争。这也是一个完美的楔子问题，因为有原则的（因此温和的）社会主义者会因哈马斯明确的种族灭绝意图而感到厌烦。

但即使在 10 月 7 日哈马斯发动袭击之前，我就已经清楚地意识到西方左派的世界观中有些东西被打破了。许多小事加起来——他们愿意将俄罗斯入侵乌克兰的责任归咎于北约，他们痴迷于不可行的经济政策，这些政策似乎是为了激起建制派民主党人的抵制，他们坚持认为美国是寡头政治而不是真正的民主国家，他们的拥抱邻避主义，他们对去增长和边缘经济理论的调情，等等。 2022 年 4 月，我写了一篇文章，表达了对整个美国左派项目的愤怒。我什至没有提到巴勒斯坦。但我已经知道有些事情不对劲了。

无论如何，这是那篇文章，我认为它已经相当陈旧了。

我非常恼火地看到诺姆·乔姆斯基在《时事》最近的一次采访中敦促乌克兰向俄罗斯让步：

我并不是在批评泽连斯基；我只是在批评他。他是一个值得尊敬的人，并且表现出了极大的勇气。你可以同情他的立场。但你也可以关注世界的现实。这就是它的含义。我回到之前所说的：基本上有两种选择。一个选择是奉行我们现在所遵循的政策，再次引用弗里曼大使的话，与俄罗斯战斗到底。是的，我们可以在可能发生核战争的情况下推行这一政策。或者我们可以面对现实，唯一的选择是外交解决，这将是丑陋的——它将给普京和他的小圈子一个逃生口……我们知道基本框架是中立乌克兰，对顿巴斯地区进行某种形式的包容，具有高度自治权，可能在乌克兰的某些联邦结构内。

这种纸上谈兵的傲慢令人震惊——美国公共知识分子在领土和外交上向乌克兰做出让步。乔姆斯基用“我们”这个词来形容他想象中将对俄罗斯做出这些让步的各方，但第一人称代词是完全没有根据的——乌克兰100%决定向侵略者投降多少领土和人民。在其占领的地区进行大规模屠杀、 大规模强奸和大规模转移到集中营。这是 0% 诺姆·乔姆斯基的决定。

想到乔姆斯基已经很老了（他已经 93 岁了！），那就太好了。但可悲的是，这比他过去所做的事情要温和。早在 1977 年，他就一直在淡化红色高棉在柬埔寨种族灭绝中的罪责：

美国公众看到的是现有证据的严重扭曲版本，强调所谓的红色高棉暴行，淡化或忽视美国在柬埔寨遭受的痛苦中直接和间接发挥的关键作用。

与此同时，接受乔姆斯基采访的《时事》杂志编辑内森·J·罗宾逊 (Nathan J. Robinson) 对外交政策的看法甚至更加令人反感。在最近的一条推文中，他断言美国的国防开支构成了“策划对俄罗斯和中国人民的种族灭绝”：

这种观点的排斥是一种异常情况，但总体而言，社会主义者并没有以他们对普京可怕且无端的乌克兰入侵的立场来掩盖自己的荣耀。例如，美国民主社会主义者国际委员会反对对乌克兰提供军事援助（如果没有这种援助，该国可能会陷落），也 反对对俄罗斯实施制裁。尽管复兴的美国社会主义运动的守护神伯尼·桑德斯(Bernie Sanders)在乌克兰战争上表现得相当不错，但伊尔汗·奥马尔(Ilhan Omar)和科里·布什(Cori Bush)确实加入了众议院特朗普派的行列，反对禁止进口俄罗斯化石燃料。社会主义杂志《雅各宾》的作者继续将这场战争部分归咎于美国和北约。等等。外交政策分析师兼中东问题专家易卜拉欣·阿西尔在俄罗斯入侵开始后不久在一条愤怒的帖子中对局势进行了很好的总结：

（当他说“进步派”时，他实际上是在谈论社会主义者；总的来说， 民主党选民非常强烈地反对普京、俄罗斯和入侵。）

当然，这并不是说社会主义左翼在这一事件中与特朗普右翼一样糟糕。但事实并非如此。但我对社会主义者的期望比对右派的期望更好——或者也许我应该说我会希望更好。事实上，同情社会主义的人可能比同情特朗普主义的人更有可能阅读我的博客，这就是为什么我花时间发泄对社会主义者的愤怒，而不是不停地咆哮为什么塔克卡尔森公司很糟糕。

在战争爆发之前，社会主义者在某种程度上转向了外交政策。他们的国内经济议程大部分已被拜登政府的大胆举措所取代——而当这些大胆举措被乔·曼钦拒绝并在民意调查中只得到冷淡支持时，这表明桑德斯总统的情况也不会更好。然而，外交政策是主流自由派和保守派之间存在更多共识的领域，因此提出了一个更具吸引力的楔子问题，社会主义者可以利用它来谴责民主党建制派。反对伊拉克战争的战斗是复兴美国社会主义运动的主要事情之一，因此发挥他们的优势是有意义的。

然后有两件事使这一转变脱轨。首先是拜登从阿富汗撤军，结束了美国在9/11之后在穆斯林国家的“永远的战争”。接下来，乌克兰战争让美国和北约坚定地扮演了好人的角色，突然介入，为勇敢的乌克兰人提供了抵御帝国主义侵略和暴行的工具。突然之间，社会主义者伪乔姆斯基式的外交政策框架——世界战争是美帝国主义造成的，而美帝国主义是由人为的同意和贪婪的军工联合体驱动的——看起来与现实脱节，甚至对欧洲的社会主义者来说也是如此。

而且它与现实脱节。但自伯尼·桑德斯(Bernie Sanders)总统竞选为社会主义运动注入新活力以来，这并不是社会主义世界观中唯一危险地转向幻想之地的部分。

美国社会主义新世界观的核心是“变革理论”。 2016 年至 2020 年间，几乎不可能不与社会主义者交谈而不听到这句话。从纯粹的选举角度来看，社会主义“变革理论”似乎是，伯尼·桑德斯拥有独特的能力，能够将传统的进步选民与从奥巴马转向特朗普的白人工人阶级选民团结起来，同时激励年轻人站出来并投票。

但伯尼根本无法做到这一点。 2020 年，他失去了 2016 年曾与他调情的白人工人阶级选民，而从未真正设法与构成民主党初选核心的黑人选民建立联系。年轻人也没有出来投票。当大多数初选选民在“超级星期二”及之后聚集在乔·拜登周围时，伯尼的支持者试图编造一个故事，说他们被建制派阴谋从背后捅了一刀，而不是简单地被选民拒绝。叙述没有采取。

“变革理论”的另一部分是“移动奥弗顿之窗”的想法。社会主义者没有将其传统定义为公共讨论的界限，而是将奥弗顿窗口重新想象为公众对什么是温和合理政策的看法。 这个想法是，通过提出非常引人注目和极端的计划，如伯尼的“全民医疗保险”计划——该计划将有效地废除私人医疗保险并消除一切形式的费用分摊，这些措施远​​远超出了欧洲社会民主国家使用的制度——社会主义者然后可以得到一个更温和的单一支付者或公共选择系统作为妥协。一些社会主义者将奥巴马医改——自医疗保险本身创建以来最重要的医疗改革—— 描述为大规模谋杀，仅仅因为这不是伯尼的计划。这是一种谈判理论——预先要求更多，最终你会得到更多，即使你没有得到你所要求的一切。

这个理论也失败了。 “全民医疗保险”一词的民意调查一直很好，但当该计划的具体细节被解释后，民意调查数字往往会急剧下降。最终，社会主义者既没有得到他们喜欢的医疗保健计划，也没有任何妥协——拜登政府和民主党国会只是简单地不再强调医疗保健，除了社会主义者之外，似乎没有人关心这一点。简单的事实是，民主党已经在一项重大的医疗改革上花费了大量政治资本，而国家没有心情重蹈覆辙。社会主义者要月亮却什么也得不到。

美国社会主义者“变革理论”的第三部分是权力理论。社会主义者声称美国的民主是由富人购买和支付的，因此我们生活在寡头政治而不是真正的民主中。 （这更像是 20 世纪初美国的进步反腐败运动，而不是基于阶级的马克思主义分析，表明美国社会主义运动的真正根源是融合的，但我离题了。）

这可能是真的，也可能不是，但到目前为止，美国是寡头政治的观点是一种基于信仰的信念，而不是任何基于证据的信念。这个想法经常被吹捧为一个科学事实，但事实上，实证支持完全依赖于吉伦斯和佩奇一篇相当平庸的政治科学论文，该论文实际上并没有说出人们认为它所说的内容，并且与其余大部分内容相矛盾。文学。我在十二月写过这个：

这篇论文还有很多问题，所以你可以去阅读马修斯的整篇文章，以及三篇评论论文。但上面摘录中引用的统计数据对于吉伦斯/佩奇的结果来说已经是完全毁灭性的了。整个模型几乎没有任何解释力——对于一个有这么多变量的模型来说，R 平方 0.074 根本不算什么。吉伦斯和佩奇的数据表明，政策结果往往与中产阶级一致，就像与富人一致一样，这一事实完全推翻了上面推文中的主张——即“民选官员制定政策是为了让最富有的 10% 的人受益”。这个国家排除了其他所有人的需求。”

当伯尼被拜登击败时，尽管伯尼拥有更大的战争资金，但这一理论开始显示出其局限性。但这个信息并没有穿透信仰之墙。当社会党候选人尼娜·特纳(Nina Turner)在民主党初选中以2比1的比分输给对手时，她声称自己并没有真正输掉，因为选举是被“黑钱”“操纵”的。

换句话说，这种关于权力和寡头政治的理论看起来主要像是在找借口——一种将社会主义者缺乏民众吸引力解释为富有的权力掮客在想象中的烟雾缭绕的密室里的阴谋的一种方式。像这样的借口可能会缓解受伤的自尊心，但它们往往不会导致自我反省。

但被打破的不仅仅是社会主义者的变革和权力理论。在具体的公共政策问题上，他们太渴望接受那些提供神奇解决方案的时尚知识分子崇拜。

其中一个例子就是“去生长”。尽管在欧洲比在美国更受欢迎，但世界必须通过大幅降低生活水平来应对气候变化的想法在这里也获得了一些认可。正如越来越多的左翼评论家开始意识到的那样，这种想法是危险的胡言乱语。没有任何规划结构可以管理全球去增长议程。但即使有可能，所需的人类福利牺牲也会使其在所有重要国家中成为不可能的事。 （而且，支持去增长的“科学”文献质量极低。） 实际上，去增长的唯一功能就是让环保主义受到憎恨和谩骂。

第二个更令人担忧的例子是左翼邻避主义。为了应对全国范围内的住房负担能力危机，全国各地的许多社会主义者都接受了这样的理论：建造更多住房会增加租金并导致中产阶级化。在全国范围内应用这显然是一个愚蠢的想法——如果你不为人们建造房屋，他们将没有地方住。但即使在地方层面，证据也强烈反对左翼邻避主义——建造更多住房会压低租金，通常会减少低收入租房者离开时尚社区的情况。但正如在许多事情上一样，证据并没有削弱社会主义的世界观——在最近的一篇文章中，内森·J·罗宾逊提出了一个滑稽的论点，即我们不应该建造新的住房，而应该简单地建造新的城市。

现在，左翼邻避主义也开始扩展到替代能源。尽管日出运动——美国新社会主义者的宠儿——一开始是促进增长的绿色新政，但该组织的地方分会现在经常反对清洁能源项目。日出组织可能开始追随塞拉俱乐部等老牌环保组织的脚步，这些组织倾向于将环保主义等同于缺乏发展。当然，这对于应对气候变化极其有害，而应对气候变化需要在全国各地迅速部署绿色能源。该组织谴责高汽油价格当然不是一个好兆头。

这已经成为一种模式；美国的社会主义者一次又一次地将他们的智力和政治资本花在这些万金油上。只有通过更明智的社会主义作家的及时干预，这场运动才免于全面陷入被称为现代货币理论的伪经济学邪教。至于反对乌克兰自卫，则带有纯粹反美“阵营主义”的味道——认为任何反对美国的人都不会那么坏，即使是普京这样的右翼独裁者。

当然，新社会主义运动中有一些好的想法，但它们常常被幻想的喧嚣所迷失和淹没。感觉美国的社会主义者正在拼凑出一个扩展的宇宙——一种幻想世界观，就像福克斯新闻所抛出的任何东西一样强大和身临其境，它提供了内部一致性的幻觉，但实际上只是历史学家理查德·霍夫施塔特(Richard Hoftstadter)所说的“美国政治中的偏执风格”。

出于多种原因，这是一种耻辱。最重要的是，美国需要一场致力于对抗经济不平等的运动，这种不平等已经完全失控。在我的一生中，感觉我们已经成为一个阶级社会，而社会主义传统上是为工人阶级的权利和权力而斗争的运动。即使超越这一狭隘的要求，西方社会的社会主义运动也常常提供异议和独立思想的重要来源。即使是我喜欢的亚文化，比如朋克摇滚，也很大程度上归功于（有时升华或被淹没的）社会主义梦想。

我想，新的美国社会主义运动对荒谬和应受谴责的事物的尝试只是成长的烦恼。但看看英国科尔宾运动和法国梅朗雄运动的更严重失败，我们很难对此感到乐观。是的，大约一半的美国年轻人说他们喜欢社会主义，但这不一定能阻止随着时间的推移该运动变成怪异的边缘——例如，自由主义观点在美国相当普遍，但几乎没有美国人认为自己是政治自由主义者。我可以很容易地想象社会主义也会走类似的道路。

因此，一群不同意识形态的人都得出了同一个结论：美国需要一个更好的官僚机构。以下是其中的一些原因。

官僚与 NEPA

也许这只是我的个人经历，但我发现当美国人说“官僚主义”这个词时，他们往往指的是“一堆规章制度和繁文缛节”，而不是“公务员制度”。这就在只想做自己事情的私营部门个人和公司与不知疲倦地执行阻止他们做自己事情的规则的公务员之间建立了隐含的二分法。

例如，这是电影《捉鬼敢死队》 （我的另一部最爱）中对环境监管的描述。我们的英雄们建立了一个私人企业来诱捕和监禁危险的幽灵。然后，环境保护局的官员沃尔特·佩克（Walter Peck）出现并告诉他们，规则禁止他们这样做，最终成功地关闭了他们（这导致了全市范围的灾难）。

这也是《辛普森一家》电影中对环境监管的描述，其中美国环保局派出一支军队占领斯普林菲尔德，并将其封入一个巨大的圆顶，试图阻止污染。

但事实上，美国最繁琐的环保监管并不是这样的！相反，我们有NEPA 等法律以及 CEQA 等更强大的州级法律，它们将环境监管的工作外包给公民和法院。它的工作方式是这样的：开发商开始开发一个项目，例如太阳能发电厂或公寓大楼。然后，出于对风景、财产价值、“邻里性格”或其他原因的担忧，不希望该项目出现在自家后院的普通公民会在法庭上起诉开发商。即使该项目从第一天起就满足所有相关环境法，公民也可以根据 NEPA 或 CEQA 起诉开发商，迫使其停止该项目并完成繁琐的环境审查——基本上是大量的文书工作。这通常会使项目延迟数年，并极大地增加成本——这当然会阻止许多开发人员从一开始就尝试构建任何东西。

通过司法程序审查来执行环境监管对美国建设我们需要的东西的能力产生了毁灭性的后果。住房项目经常被邻避者利用环境审查法起诉开发商，往往以最荒谬的借口（例如将公寓大楼的人类噪音标记为一种污染）。我们经济脱碳所需的太阳能发电厂、 电池工厂和输电线路的建设速度并没有达到应有的速度，因为它们受到了这些审查法律的阻碍。请记住，大多数这些项目从一开始就没有违反任何环境审查法——邻避者有权起诉并阻止开发，无论是否实际上违反了任何法规！

这就提出了一个明显的问题：除了等待诉讼和多年的环境审查之外，我们如何知道是否没有违反环境法规？答案是：官僚。答案是，你让一群政府工作人员检查该项目，并确保它检查了所有相关的监管框，然后如果符合，你只需允许该项目继续进行，无需诉讼或多年研究。这称为“部委批准”或“部委审查”。这就是日本的行事方式，这就是为什么他们能够建造足够的住房以保持租金负担得起。

邻避者绝对害怕部长级审查。我强烈建议您阅读乔丹·格莱姆斯 (Jordan Grimes) 撰写的这篇帖子，其中详细介绍了邻避压力团体对加州一系列新的支持住房法的不满。对于新住房的反对者来说，最可怕的前景是“正当”开发，这意味着官僚可以决定是否允许住房项目，而不是通过诉讼和法官。

换句话说，环境监管不会通过由一大批一丝不苟的官僚机构执行的大量繁文缛节来威胁美国经济。它通过大量的诉讼和毫无意义的文书工作来威胁美国的经济，我们实施这些文书工作是为了替代雇用一大批一丝不苟的官僚队伍。如果我们废除这种法律许可制度并用一大群官僚取而代之，我们仍然能够很好地保护环境，但我们将能够做到这一点，而不会造成疯狂的多年延误和将成本推向月球。

The nine most terrifying words in the English language are not “I'm from the Government and I'm here to help”. Nine far more terrifying words are: “Please spend four years completing your Environmental Impact Statement.”

Bureaucrats vs. nonprofits and consultants

Even as environmental regulation has been outsourced to the courts, a huge variety of other government functions have been outsourced to nonprofits. In a post back in May, I argued that this represented a toxic compromise between anti-government conservatives who wanted to shrink the state and progressives who wanted to increase community input into policymaking:

Some excerpts from that post:

We do know that about a third of nonprofit funding comes from government purchases and grants, and that nonprofit revenue rose by about 70% in inflation-adjusted terms from 1998 to 2016. A rough back-of-the-envelope calculation — $2.62 trillion in nonprofit revenue in 2016, 32.3% from government — says that this would equate to around $850 billion in government spending on nonprofits in the US

That's about 13% of all government spending, including state and local, spent via nonprofits. Compare that to about 18.4% of government spending spent on actual government workers as of 2022. We've outsourced a significant amount of our government to nonprofits. Here's a brief overview of some of the ways this work is outsourced. Of course the number includes things like public university funding (universities are also nonprofits). But a lot of it is just paying organizations to administer government spending.

Outsourcing government functions to nonprofits — which is definitely a form of privatization, even if no one is officially making a profit — has a number of problems. First there's the obvious danger of corruption, in which nonprofits line their pockets by using taxpayer money to help elect leaders who give them more taxpayer money. Of course this money is paid out in executive salaries rather than “profit”, but it amounts to the same thing.

But even more important is what economists call an “agency problem”. Nonprofits would rather get the government to give them as much money as possible; they would love to rip the government off. And if all the expertise involved in building housing or providing social services resides in the nonprofits instead of the government itself, the government doesn't have the ability to judge whether it's getting ripped off . Here's how I put it in my earlier post:

When the government controls the purse strings but only the contractors know how much things should really cost, you get the worst of both worlds — a government that doesn't know how to save taxpayer money, paying contractors who don't want to save taxpayer money.

This problem is especially acute in San Francisco, which makes it extremely difficult to hire workers for the civil service, and has taken nonprofit-outsourcing to an extreme. (In fact, if you want to read a fun satire about nonprofit-outsourcing in SF in the late 60s and 70s, check out Tom Wolfe's essay “ Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers ”.) Investigations have shown that oversight of SF nonprofits has been extremely poor — in part because the city got rid of the bureaucrats who could have done that monitoring effectively. Massive inefficiencies are allowed to fester for years, only coming to light after elected officials discover the problems and raise the alarm. The most recent blowup I've seen is over an addiction treatment nonprofit:

A San Francisco supervisor is calling for an audit of the city's largest addiction treatment nonprofit after word leaked that a staffing shortage forced the organization's detox program to pause intakes last week…

HealthRight 360 is the largest drug treatment provider in San Francisco and is slated to receive more than $200 million from the city this fiscal year, according to a city database.

“This is not to cast aspersions on anyone, but I am truly concerned that we are paying for a service that they're not able to provide,” Stefani said at Tuesday's hearing.

Of course this doesn't mean that bureaucrats always have the right incentives. With the wrong funding incentives, civil service agencies can fall into a trap in which they try to maximize the amount they spend each year in order to increase their budgets for future years. An efficient bureaucracy requires avoiding perverse incentives like that. But when the funds are being spent via nonprofits instead of government workers, the incentives are much harder to get right, because the government lacks most of the levers of control that it has over its own workforce.

Of course, the agency problems doesn't just apply to nonprofits, but to any government contractors. And when it comes to transportation planning, a huge problem is the amount that governments have come to rely on consultants. The Transit Cost Project has been looking into the question of why it costs so much more to build each mile of train in the US than in other rich countries (most of which have stronger unions). Their big report , released earlier this year, found that state and local governments' excessive reliance on outside consultants rather than in-house bureaucratic expertise was a huge driver of excess cost. Here are some excerpts from a great writeup by Henry Grabar:

[M]any of the [transit cost] problems can be traced to a larger philosophy: outsourcing government expertise to a retainer of consultants…

For example, when the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority got to work on the Green Line Extension, the agency only had a half-dozen full-time employees managing the largest capital project the MBTA had ever undertaken. On New York's Second Avenue subway, the most expensive mile of subway ever built, consultant contracts were more than 20 percent of construction costs—more than double what's standard in France or Italy. By 2011, the MTA had trimmed its in-house capital projects management group of 1,600 full-time employees (circa 1990) to just 124, tasked with steering $20 billion in investment. Perhaps the most notorious case in this business is the debacle of the California High-Speed Rail project, which in its early years had a tiny full-time staff managing hundreds of millions of dollars in consulting contracts …

It's that lack of institutional know-how, of which consultants are both a symptom and a cause, that really hampers projects…It means staff are overwhelmed by change orders as projects evolve. In the case of New York's Second Avenue subway, the lack of a powerful, effective team of civil servants may also explain some inexplicable conflicts and mistakes: misunderstandings and feuds with local agencies, hugely overbuilt stations, and so little standardization that the escalators in the three new stops were built by three different companies.

Would replacing some of these consultants with government bureaucrats really lower costs? A recent paper by Zachary Liscow, William Nober, and Cailin Slattery suggests that it would:

[W]e find evidence that state capacity correlates inversely with costs in a several ways. States with (perceived) higher quality DOT employees have lower costs. A state with a neutral rating has almost 30% higher costs per mile than one that rates the DOT employees as “moderately high quality”, all else equal. Consistent with the capacity hypothesis, states that flag concerns about consultant costs have higher costs.承包商和采购官员预计变更单较多的州的成本会显着升高。 Frequent change orders could directly lead to higher costs through delays and costly renegotiation; they could also be a downstream symptom of poor administrative capacity at a state DOT—many contractors reference poor-quality project plans made by third-party consultants. Moreover, when we measure capacity using external data we show that states with higher DOT capacity have lower infrastructure costs. A one standard deviation increase in capacity is correlated with 16% lower costs.

And a recent paper by Maggie Shi finds that when the government monitors Medicare spending more closely, it reduces waste by a huge amount:

Every dollar Medicare spent on monitoring generated $24–29 in government savings. The majority of savings stem from the deterrence of future care, rather than reclaimed payments from prior care. I do not find evidence that the health of the marginal patient is harmed, indicating that monitoring primarily deters low-value care. Monitoring does increase provider administrative costs, but these costs are mostly incurred upfront and include investments in technology to assess the medical necessity of care.

And guess who's responsible for monitoring Medicare spending? Bureaucrats. So that's at least a 2300% return on investment in bureaucracy!

In sum, the years since the 1970s have been a massive experiment in whether a government, by outsourcing core functions to private actors like nonprofits and consultants, can increase the efficiency with which public funds are spent. That experiment has failed , and it needs to be reversed.

Preparing for the next threat

I became painfully aware of the problems of a weak bureaucracy during the early days of the Covid pandemic. I started a group to help encourage state public health agencies to improve contact tracing — an approach that ultimately proved futile due to hyper-infectious mutations. But back when the virus was less contagious and we still thought contact tracing might work, my partners and I had some meetings with government workers at the CDC. It was clear that they had absolutely no resources to commit to our project, and that they were overwhelmed with other demands.

Perhaps that's to be expected in the middle of a massive pandemic. But it was also clear that the CDC workers we talked to didn't know a lot of basic facts about how their organization worked; there was lots of data that they had no idea how to find, or even who was responsible for collecting it, and they had little concept of who was responsible for contact tracing at the state level. Those are things they should have known long before the pandemic even started.

In fact, the pathetic crisis performance of the CDC — which before the pandemic was often believed to be one of our most competent government agencies — is now the stuff of legend . Most damningly, the agency was unable to collect even the most basic data on the spread of the virus — data that private individuals were forced to collect in its stead. In addition, it made numerous bad recommendations that were later reversed, issued confusing guidance, and failed to develop Covid tests in the early days of the pandemic. The agency is now being reformed , but it's not yet clear how deep the reforms go.

But what I'm most afraid of is not another pandemic; it's a major war. In a widely-read post last week, I warned that a war with China over Taiwan is a lot more likely than most Americans seem to realize, and that we need to be preparing for that grim possibility right now. China's state apparatus is famously effective in building large amounts of stuff very quickly — in the space of just a few years, while the US was failing to build even a small amount of high-speed rail, China built a high-speed rail network that dwarfed American transit advocates' wildest dreams. In a war situation, China's massive production advantage means that the US will be at a dramatic disadvantage in a protracted conflict. We do not have the equivalent of the effective bureaucracies that we created in the runup to World War 2.

But even beyond military production, the US needs to do lots of preparation for the possibility of a China conflict. Private companies need to audit their supply chains to make sure they can sustain production in the event of a war. The US government needs to ensure that critical minerals can be accessed without reliance on Chinese processing facilities. And the government needs to revive the defense-industrial base, so we don't see bottlenecks of the kind we encountered when we tried to produce Covid masks, tests, and ventilators in the early days of the pandemic.

All of this requires a large, competent, well-funded bureaucracy. Yet I worry that neither progressives nor conservatives understand this need. Progressives still seem wedded to the idea of defending NEPA , while conservatives still seem wedded to the idea of slashing and burning any government agency they can . It's a toxic equilibrium in which one side wants to drown the government in a bathtub and the other wants to outsource it to every NIMBY and nonprofit in the country.

To reestablish US state capacity, we have to sail between the rocks of both of these disastrous approaches. We have to rebuild the civil service, with sufficient long-term funding guarantees, talent, and size. For all our sake, we need to bring back the bureaucrats.

“No!完全错误！打开城门！” — 冯·孟乔森男爵

在本周的综述中，我赞同马克·安德森的“技术乐观主义宣言”。我注意到了一些不同意见，但总的来说，我认为这种毫不妥协的技术加速主义浪潮正是我们所需要的那种外向热情，可以让我们摆脱 2010 年代的低迷。

但马克的宣言仍然没有完全阐明我对技术乐观主义的看法；当然，有很多重叠之处，但我认为用我自己的话重新表述这个想法可以收获很多，所以当我说我是“技术乐观主义者”时，人们确切地知道这意味着什么。

嗯，这就是我的意思。

不同类型的乐观：积极与规范、积极与消极

当人们使用“乐观”这个词时，他们可能有不同的含义，所以我认为最好从分类开始。首先，谈到技术进步，基本上有两件事是可以乐观的：

  1. 您可以认为还有很多有用的技术有待发现。

  2. 你可以认为新技术会让世界变得更美好。

借用经济学术语，我可以将这些称为“积极的”和“规范的”技术乐观主义。

很明显，这些不是同一件事。例如，我经常说我对未来十年自主无人机技术将取得巨大进步感到“乐观”。但我也认为这将主要用于战争，而不是用于运送包裹等民用应用。现在这对人类来说不一定是坏消息——未来战争演变成机器人在空中与其他机器人作战可能意味着死亡人数会大大减少。我只是不太相信强大的新军事技术会改善人类福祉。我对这些技术的可能性充满信心。

积极的技术乐观主义基本上与停滞主义相反。近年来，许多思想家开始表示，人类基本上已经摘取了宇宙所能做到的唾手可得的果实，未来的创新将变得更加昂贵，甚至缓慢到涓涓细流。积极的技术乐观主义认为，不，仍然有很多唾手可得的成果，而且相对于我们的 GDP 总量，找到它的成本仍然不高。

规范的技术乐观主义则不同。它说更多的技术将使世界变得更加美好。事实上，这种技术乐观主义非常罕见——即使是我最喜欢的一些科幻故事也隐含或明确地围绕着这样一个想法：无论我们的能力如何提高，人类基本的野蛮本性永远不会改变。据我所知，这种非常普遍的态度来自20世纪的世界大战，1914年之前用于提高生活水平的工业技术变成了破坏性目的。有一些人认为，更多的技术让我们成为更好的人——史蒂夫·平克在《我们本性的更好的天使》中提出了这一论点，我认为这是洛伊丝·麦克马斯特·布约德科幻小说的隐含前提。

这是一个区别。对于这两种情况，您可以定义积极和消极的乐观形式。被动乐观基本上只是相信技术要么会持续快速进步，要么会改善人类的生活，无论我们做什么。积极乐观主义认为，只有我们人类采取适当的行动来确保这种情况发生，技术才会不断进步和/或改善人类生活。积极的乐观主义就是葛兰西等人所说的“意志的乐观主义”。您也可以将这些称为“无条件”和“有条件”乐观。

所以你可以定义一个二乘二的图表：

显然，这些并不都是相互排斥的。例如，你可能认为技术进步是不可避免的，但只有我们选择正确的政策，它才会造福人类。或者你可以相信，只有我们选择正确的政策，技术进步才会持续下去，但如果它持续下去，它自然会对世界有利。 ETC。

就我个人而言，我赞成积极的和规范的技术乐观主义，但对这两种情况都持保留态度。我认为还有很多新的重要发现有待实现，但我确实认为寻找它们的成本可能会变得更高。我还认为技术通常最终会让大多数人的生活变得更好，但情况并非总是如此。

不过，在这两种情况下，我都是一个积极的乐观主义者，而不是消极的乐观主义者。无论是维持创新速度还是确保创新造福人类，我认为选择正确的政策非常重要。

那么让我来解释一下我为什么这么想。

技术乐观主义是人文主义

当美国人想到“技术”时，他们往往会想到一些复杂的机器——也许是带有屏幕的东西。但我更喜欢从日语单词“技术”的意义上来思考它，它也可以表示“技术”或“技能”。这是一个更为笼统的定义，基本上也是经济学家思考技术的方式。

在经济学中，技术的作用是扩大社会可以消费的物品范围——换句话说，它扩大了我们的集体选择范围。这并不意味着它总是扩大个人选择——例如，在互联网和手机时代，脱离电网要困难得多。但如果人类集体想要的话，我们就可以回到一个很容易脱离电网的世界；互联网和手机让我们可以选择是否这样做，而在 1960 年我们没有这样的选择。

增加人类集体选择的想法与GDP的经济概念密切相关。 GDP 是由人们选择为我们生产的产品支付的总额来定义的；换句话说，这只是人类选择的一种衡量标准。这并不是一个完美的对应关系，因为 GDP 遗漏了一些东西（休闲、不平等等）。但这是非常密切相关的。这就是为什么很多人通过指向这样的图表来谈论技术的好处：

当然，GDP总量代表两件事：每个人为物品支付多少钱，以及有多少人支付。这在某种程度上与我们可以利用更多的资源来创造更多的人类，或者提高现有人类的生活水平的想法有关。这是不一样的，因为国内生产总值并不等于资源使用（去增长论者总是犯错误）。但确实，全球国内生产总值的增长使我们能够提高人口数量和生活水平。

这两者都代表了人类的集体选择。事实上，这些选择可能会随着时间而改变。随着技术的进步，人类选择生育越来越少的孩子，世界人口在不久的将来可能会减少。如果这就是我们决定想要的，那就这样吧。

我认为技术进步通常对人类有益——为什么我是“规范”类型的技术乐观主义者——的主要原因是我从根本上相信人类应该被给予尽可能多的选择。这不是我可以用事实证明的事情——这只是一种道德直觉。我是一个人文主义者。我看到人们想要东西，我想给他们他们想要的东西。这并不总是意味着人类在得到他们想要的东西时会更快乐；有时我们会做出让我们不快乐的选择。但作为一名人文主义者，我相信我的物种有选择的权利。

但请记住，集体选择与个人选择不同。社会做出的许多选择与个人做出的选择相悖——例如当社会因犯罪而将你投入监狱时。规范的、人文主义的技术乐观主义要求人们相信，从长远来看，平均而言，社会做出的选择也会导致更多的个人选择——某种自由主义最终将占上风。所以这也有点像福山万的想法。它需要一种信念，即社会——总体而言，最终——会做对个人有利的事情。

这种信念往往不会成功。苏联发明了相当多的重要技术，但它为了追求最终证明自己是反人道主义的意识形态而使人民陷入贫困。我也不认为专制社会必然会失败——看看中国的经济主导地位和日益加强的极权控制就知道了。事实上，中国利用新技术建立新型数字极权主义对我的技术乐观主义提出了严峻的挑战。但我认为那里的情况仍然比文化大革命期间或几个世纪前要好得多。

我还担心人类的集体选择会伤害那些没有发言权的人——即动物。我们最终可能成为自然世界的好管家，富裕国家已经朝着这个方向采取了明确的行动。但到目前为止，我们人口和生产的扩张已经给我们的大多数动物同胞带来了毁灭，因为我们的选择与他们的选择不同。所以这削弱了我对技术的乐观态度，我认为这是我们需要解决的问题。

但无论如何，技术乐观主义的核心是相信人类应该对宇宙有更多的集体控制。尽管有一些保留，但总的来说我确实相信这一点。我不会让地球回到1000年、1800年、1971年的状态。（至于是否回到2012年， 几年后问我吧。）

为什么还有很多技术有待发现

我也是一个“积极”的技术乐观主义者——我认为我们还有很多有用的东西有待发现。我之所以相信这一点，是因为技术本身的本质阻止了人类发现它。

Let me explain what that means.当一个人做出一项科学发现或发明一种新的制造技术或其他什么时，他们通常会因此获得一些荣誉——升职和加薪，或者一些智力上的认可。有时，如果他们围绕自己的创新建立了一家成功的公司，他们甚至会获得巨额金钱奖励。但总的来说，一项新创新的大部分好处都属于那些没有花费任何努力或金钱来发现它的人。它属于模仿者和“快速追随者”，他们复制或逆向工程或窃取新技术。它将授予基于这一发现的其他创新者。等等。

这就是所谓的“正外部性”。事实上，科学本身非常接近经济学家所说的“纯粹的公共物品”，除了在战时。经济学告诉我们的一件事是，公共物品的供给不足；创新的动力没有应有的那么强烈。 （这对于任何具有正外部性的事物都是如此，而不仅仅是公共物品！）为什么我应该在实验室里度过一生来发现别人可以货币化的东西？因此，没有足够多的人在实验室度过一生。

（这就是马克所说的技术创新是“慈善事业”时的意思。显然，慈善事业远远不足以解决大多数社会弊病，同样，出于对创新的热爱而创新也远远不足以推动技术快速进步。正如它应该发生的那样。）

我们的社会已经制定了许多机制来解决创新不足的问题。我们给予创新者专利垄断权，以增加他们的经济回报（尽管这也会因为制造专利流氓而损害一些创新）。我们利用政府来资助基础研究——不仅是基础科学，还包括应用研究。我们为企业研发提供税收抵免。

我对未来进步的机会持乐观态度，因为我相信这些措施仍然远远不够。合理的模型表明，就 GDP 增长而言，增加研发支出的经济回报仍然非常高。这意味着，如果我们花更多的钱——或者以其他方式激励创新——我们就会更快地发现和发明更多的东西。

有证据表明新技术越来越难找到，这是相当合理的。在 1600 年代，一个人在相当简陋的实验室中进行修补就可以发现宇宙的基本定律；现在可能仍然有可能，但现在这种情况已经很少发生了。一些新领域，如合成生物学，在某种程度上适合在孤独爱好者的车库里进行廉价创新，但其他领域，如人工智能，需要大量的物理资源才能突破极限。

但随着新发现的平均成本越来越高，我们的社会变得更加富裕，并且更有能力承担持续创新所需的不断增加的支出。这就是为什么至少在短期内，我乐观地认为还有很多东西有待发现。

当然，这需要我们采取正确的政策——同样的外部性让我确信还有很多东西有待发现，这也是我们可能无法发现它的原因。特别是，我在这里担心两件事。首先，我担心富裕国家（尤其是美国）的政治混乱和分裂将使我们不太愿意为研发提供资金——已经出现了令人担忧的迹象，例如国会暂停了两党 CHIPS 法案的科学资助。其次，我担心中国盗窃知识产权的规模如此之大，导致其他国家的创新回报率下降。

所以我是一个意志上的技术乐观主义者，但我们需要意志，而这并不是一件容易聚集的事情。

“全力以赴”的技术进步方法

由于维持技术进步非常困难，因此需要采取全社会的方法才能实现这一目标。这不是只有大公司、风投资助的初创公司、大学、政府等才能充分处理的事情。这些不同的创新者都专注于不同的技术领域，并有不同的激励措施结构，所以我们都需要它们。

技术的实施需要更广泛的机构。如果我们不能通过NEPA来建造绿色能源技术，那么即使绿色能源技术变得非常便宜也没关系。苏联是第一个进入太空的国家，但他们的太空计划并没有真正帮助他们的人民（与美国不同，美国的太空计划确实帮助了他们）。

我们推动技术进步所需的机构范围之广令人惊讶。马克在他的宣言中列出了各种“敌人”——不是人，而是他认为限制技术发展的思想和机构。其中一些，例如去生长，属于该列表。但他的一些“敌人”根本不是敌人，而是需要拉拢来推动更快创新的重要机构。这些包括：

  • 国家主义和中央计划

  • 官僚

  • 垄断

我已经谈到了为什么政府对于加速技术进步很重要，如果你具体考虑这一点，很难想象重大技术突破不涉及公私合作。 Covid 疫苗及其引发的 mRNA 创新浪潮只是最新的例子，但曼哈顿计划开启了核时代（政府资助对核能至关重要），人类基因组计划发起了遗传学革命，DARPA 帮助创建了互联网等。 NSF、NIH、DARPA、BARDA、NASA、国家实验室……都有着推动创新进程的传奇历史（通常会给美国带来巨大利益）。这不是传统苏联意义上的“中央计划”，但它肯定是国家主义的。

至于官僚主义，这肯定会损害技术进步，但如果处理得当，它可以带来很大的帮助。例如，看看 NEPA——这项法律允许私人公民将项目在法庭上捆绑多年，做繁琐的文书工作，即使它们已经满足了所有环境法——对我们在美国建造物理技术的能力做了什么影响。 NEPA 之类的替代方案是一个有能力、高效的官僚机构，可以快速确定项目是否符合环境法，如果符合则迅速批准。这就是为什么越来越多的自由主义者认识到国家能力的至关重要性。

最后，垄断肯定会阻碍经济活动。但很难忽视这样一个事实，即我们许多最重要的科学发现和技术创新——包括信息技术革命的两个重要支柱——晶体管和生成式人工智能——都来自大型垄断公司的企业实验室。贝尔实验室的创新历史是传奇，有一天谷歌在人工智能基础研究领域的主导地位也将成为传奇。重要的是，贝尔和谷歌虽然都是垄断企业，但最终都没有从他们的发现中获得大部分利益。由于它们是垄断企业，并且拥有巨大的利润缓冲来资助研究，因此它们能够暂时忽视技术创新的外部性问题，更像是政府实验室或大学，而不是追求利润的公司。

因此，如果有人认为技术的发展完全是由车库里斗志旺盛的发明家推动的，而政府和大企业只是从他们的劳动中获取利益，那就大错特错了。任何认为技术完全由政府规划者推动、而私营部门只是依赖于政府努力的人也是大错特错。技术的外部性问题足够深刻和复杂，社会需要“全力以赴”的创新方式——我们的各个机构必须相互补充和补充，各自朝不同的方向推动技术的边界，并共同努力当适用。

社会是技术的用户体验

令人沮丧的是，大量的人似乎认为技术和社会从根本上来说是竞争的——一方面是不道德的科学家和贪婪的技术兄弟之间的斗争，另一方面是社会责任和更大利益的力量的斗争。这种世界观认为，技术专家本质上是一种海盗，在公海上航行寻找掠夺品，而社会责任海军则四处追赶他们。

在我看来，这种看待事物的方式是错误的，而且会适得其反。原因是，正如我之前所说，技术本质上是一项人文事业——它增加了人类社会可用的集体选择。

这意味着两件事。首先，这意味着创造新技术的根本目的是为社会赋能。如果你正在研究一种新的癌症药物或新的图像识别人工智能或新的半导体制造工艺，你所做的就是给社会更多的选择——给人们提供多少更多的癌症治疗，是否建立更好的图像搜索系统或实施普遍监视，要制造多少计算量以及将其用于什么目的，等等。社会做出哪些选择取决于社会；如果你是创新者，你就不是把权力交到自己手中，而是把权力交到社会手中。

科学家和工程师拒绝开发某些技术（核武器、人工智能等）的所有著名论点都基于这样的观点：社会没有能力就如何使用这些东西做出正确的选择，并且个人（科学家和发明家本身）更有能力做出决定。一旦你发明或发现了某种东西，它的使用方式就不再由你掌控了，所以技术专家真正违背社会意愿的唯一方法就是拒绝创新。创新需要对社会的信任，而缺乏信任最终会导致减速主义冲动。

社会和技术不可分割的第二个原因是，社会本身就是我之前提出的更一般意义上的技术。具体来说，社会是其他技术的用户体验（UX）；它决定了人类如何体验技术带来的力量。

要理解这一点，请考虑数字监控技术。美国和中国选择以截然不同的方式使用这些技术。在美国，您可能会使用网络摄像头来跟踪您的宠物兔子，或者拍摄有趣的视频，或者直播自己玩视频游戏，或者进行各种其他令人愉快的追求。在中国你也可以做这些事情，但是当你这样做的时候，隐私就少得多，因为国家一直在监视。除了这些个人有趣的用途之外，中国还使用网络摄像机创建了一个数字圆形监狱，公民永远无法摆脱国家的窥视。对于这个国家的少数民族来说，这座圆形监狱就像乔治·奥威尔小说中的任何东西一样可怕。

换句话说，社会有责任利用技术行善，而不是作恶。有时这可能需要很长时间才能弄清楚——印刷机等印刷媒体技术在首次引入时造成了很多破坏和冲突，只有随着时间的推移，我们才学会如何负责任地使用它们。我预计社交媒体现在也会发生类似的情况。我们花了很多年的时间才实施了使工厂工作变得可以忍受而不是地狱般的劳动法规，使肉类、汽车和航空旅行对公众来说更加安全的消费者保护措施，以及净化了我们的空气和水的环境法规。一路走来，我们的社会犯了许多错误（例如 NEPA），我们现在必须纠正这些错误。

尽管这是一个困难的过程，但却是完全必要的。技术的目的是造福人类（希望有一天也造福动物和其他众生），而社会的作用是弄清楚如何广泛分配这些好处。当然，这不包括社会在支持创新方面的作用。

换句话说，技术与社会之间没有界限。它们是一个统一实体的一部分——其范围比“技术元素”本身还要广泛。它们是人类有机体的组成部分。

可持续发展就是技术

最后，我想谈谈可持续发展。马克在他的宣言中指出，“可持续性”（用引号引起来）是技术乐观主义的敌人之一。不过，虽然他可能指的是那些在可持续发展的虚假旗帜下掩盖去增长想法的人，但实际的可持续发展并不是技术乐观主义的敌人。确实，它是其中的核心部分。能够将技术社会维持到无限的未来本身就是创新的基本目标。而实现这一目标的方法几乎总是更多的创新，而不是更少。

考虑一个想象中的简单小例子——一个经济体只有一小群人和维持他们生计的果树林。人们无法消化种子，因此种子要么被扔掉，要么通过消化道，最终为新的果树施肥，这样的小循环就得以维持。但后来人们发明了一种技术，可以让他们煮熟并消化种子。这会在短期内增加他们的热量摄入；如果我们衡量 GDP 和消费，我们会看到两者都会上升。但由于煮熟种子会阻止果树繁殖，最终水果会枯死，人们会挨饿。哎呀！

这个问题的解决办法是什么？嗯，一种相当令人不满意的解决方案是去生长；人们可以简单地不煮种子，以便它们保持旧的平衡。但更好的解决方案是更多的技术。如果人们发明了一种将种子集中培育成新树的方法，他们今天就可以煮食一些种子，并以受控的方式种植其余的种子，这样他们仍然可以无限期地维持果园。技术让他们陷入了麻烦，但最终技术也让他们摆脱了麻烦。

事实上，这种创新很常见，你可以在这里看到与化石燃料非常接近的类比。大自然赋予人类丰富的煤炭、石油和天然气，但最终这些燃料的开采成本变得更加昂贵——这甚至没有考虑到气候变化的影响。技术可以在一段时间内保持开采成本低廉，但最终会耗尽。但如果我们利用化石燃料支持的工业社会来创造更稳定的替代品——太阳能和最终的聚变能——那么我们将能够比永远坚持使用化石燃料更长久地维持和发展工业社会。

更一般地说，技术进步就是明天比今天更好。如果没有明天，今天就更不重要了；令人难以置信的光明未来的承诺是我们今天如此努力创新和挑战极限的主要原因。泰勒·考恩（Tyler Cowen）的《顽固依恋》 （Stubborn Attachments）一书有力地、有说服力地提出了这一点。我们不仅仅为自己创新；我们为自己和子孙后代进行创新。

技术乐观主义的敌人不是可持续性，而是可持续性。这是短期主义。人类不应该创造新事物来提高季度收入；我们应该建造它们，以便我们的后代，无论他们以何种形式，都将拥有世界和星星。如果我们要永久拥有世界和星星，我们就必须小心不要掠夺它们，从我们现在坐的那个开始。

因此，技术乐观主义不仅仅是关于当今机构或当今资源分配的争论。这是对人类以及所有众生的信念，推动我们迈向无限的明天。

本周还没有新的播客，但我确实有一个不寻常的请求。正如该博客的老读者所知，我在生活中最关心的一件事就是照顾兔子。我同样喜欢猫和狗，但兔子却没有得到那么多的关注，因此它们经常受到非常恶劣的对待。我自己的兔子是在 2016 年从一个试图在车库里非法饲养兔子的人手中救出来的，当时的条件绝对是可怕的。

Anyway, there was another similar rescue in the Bay Area recently, in Petaluma — dozens of rabbits saved from very cruel living conditions. The rabbit rescue that originally rescued my own rabbits, SaveABunny, reached out and asked if I knew anyone who might be able to help. So if you're in the Bay Area, and you also like rabbits, and you think you might want to help take care of one, please email them at rescue@saveabunny.org, or go to their website , or respond to their Facebook post .

Anyway, on to this week's Five Interesting Things.

1. Techno-optimism resurgent

As you know, I'm a dogged techno-optimist . I think we consistently underrate the power of science and technology to change our world for the better, and we underinvest in both. (You can expect my review of Power and Progress , whose central thesis is that techno-optimist ideas have deeply damaged our economy, to be a feisty one.) But there are people out there whose techno-optimism is so intense that it puts my own in the shade. One of these is Marc Andreessen .

In a new essay/rant called “ The Techno-Optimist Manifesto ” over at a16z's website, Marc lays out his vision. Here are a few points I'd like to highlight.

First, Marc focuses squarely on technology's ability to bring abundance . And he appropriately frames abundance not just as “more stuff”, but as more choice in general for human beings, and more control over our world.

We are materially focused, for a reason – to open the aperture on how we may choose to live amid material abundance.

A common critique of technology is that it removes choice from our lives as machines make decisions for us. This is undoubtedly true, yet more than offset by the freedom to create our lives that flows from the material abundance created by our use of machines.

Material abundance from markets and technology opens the space for religion, for politics, and for choices of how to live, socially and individually.

We believe technology is liberatory. Liberatory of human potential. Liberatory of the human soul, the human spirit. Expanding what it can mean to be free, to be fulfilled, to be alive.

We believe technology opens the space of what it can mean to be human.

I couldn't agree more, and I think this is extremely well-put.

This is also a very important paragraph:

We believe there is no conflict between capitalist profits and a social welfare system that protects the vulnerable. In fact, they are aligned – the production of markets creates the economic wealth that pays for everything else we want as a society.

Degrowthers — whom Marc correctly identifies as an enemy of human progress — believe that there's an inherent tradeoff between human abundance and nature. This is a story of technology as fundamentally extractive, which fits neatly into a zero-sum worldview where prosperity is all about the extraction of resources rather than the creation of novelty. But Marc correctly realizes that technology is what allows humanity to reduce our natural footprint even as we create abundance for ourselves:

Natural resource utilization has sharp limits, both real and political…And so the only perpetual source of growth is technology…We believe technology is a lever on the world – the way to make more with less.

I also agree with Marc that culture matters. The last ten years have been a decade of unrest in American society, in which existing status hierarchies were unsettled and challenged across our entire culture. Because technologists and tech companies often make a lot of money and are thus high on the status totem pole, a fair amount of ire was directed their way. (The highest intellectual expression of that ire is the book Power and Progress , which I'm currently in the middle of reviewing.) Marc's essay lashes out at these critics:

Our present society has been subjected to a mass demoralization campaign for six decades – against technology and against life – under varying names like “existential risk”, “sustainability”, “ESG”, “Sustainable Development Goals”, “social responsibility”, “stakeholder capitalism”, “Precautionary Principle”, “trust and safety”, “tech ethics”, “risk management”, “de-growth”, “the limits of growth”.

Here I take a more balanced view, but still ultimately come down on Marc's side. Some of the ideas and institutions he lists as the “enemy” are useless, but many of them have some value. Sustainability, for example, is actually a goal of technological progress — as Marc himself acknowledges earlier. Existential risk is an important thing to worry about, which is why nerds celebrate the day that Stanislav Petrov's judgement saved us from a nuclear war.

But Marc is right that most of the forces and institutions that have set themselves up as enemies of techno-capital were given extra force and virulence by the general climate of unrest in America (the unsettling of status hierarchies being what Marc, referencing Nietzsche, refers to as “ressentiment”). So Marc is right that it's time for a useful corrective — a general social refocusing on technological progress, abundance, and optimism.

There is one area where I might disagree with Marc, though. While he's right that markets are a crucial engine of innovation, I do think he underestimates the role of government in pressing science and technology forward:

We believe central planning is a doom loop; markets are an upward spiral.

The economist William Nordhaus has shown that creators of technology are only able to capture about 2% of the economic value created by that technology. The other 98% flows through to society in the form of what economists call social surplus. Technological innovation in a market system is inherently philanthropic , by a 50:1 ratio. Who gets more value from a new technology, the single company that makes it, or the millions or billions of people who use it to improve their lives? QED.

But in fact, the second paragraph explains exactly why the first sentence in this quote isn't quite right. It's precisely because innovators don't capture most of the monetary benefits of the innovations they create that we need some other force to propel technology forward. Yes, invention is philanthropy, and philanthropy isn't enough!

That's where government comes in. There are plenty of ways that government can and does encourage accelerated innovation — through R&D tax credits, through the patent system (sometimes), though funding of basic research at universities and national labs, through DARPA, and so on. Much of our technological innovation has been driven by this support, which works in harmony with markets instead of replacing them. In fact, Marc himself created the first widely usable graphical web browser while working at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications , a state-funded research center! And Marc correctly lists Paul Romer as a patron saint of techno-optimism; Romer has fought tirelessly for more government funding for science and technology.

If you don't want to call that “central planning”, fine. But don't forget the important role of government in pushing progress forward!

Here's a good thread by Nick Pinkston making the same point.

Anyway, Marc is just one of a whole new crop of techno-optimists that has popped up in recent years. The e/acc movement — basically an online reboot of the extropian movement from the 1990s — is extremely fun. My favorite e/acc account is @terrorproforma .

Meanwhile, Packy McCormick, who writes the excellent Substack Not Boring , has a new series called “Age of Miracles” where he explores new technologies:

And of course there's no shortage of actual technological miracles happening all around us. Malaria vaccines — created using the same technology that we deployed to fight Covid — are now being deployed, threatening to free humanity (and especially Africa) from one of our most terrible and deadly endemic diseases.

And that turbulence you hate whenever you fly on a plane? Well, that might soon be mostly a thing of the past, thanks to AI:

(Update: This may actually be done without AI! If so, that's pretty amazing in and of itself.)

In fact, the combination of AI and physical technology promises to create a whole new era of innovation in “atoms”.

It's a pretty great time to be alive. Time to shake off the malaise of the 2010s and dream big again.

2. The US economy remains undefeated

Usually you wouldn't think of a US economic boom as the type of story to fly under the radar…right? And yet the US' economic outperformance during the post-pandemic years, and especially over the last year, feels very underappreciated. Let's look at a few charts.

First, there's growth. Even as China and Europe have decelerated since the pandemic, the US has grown faster than pre-pandemic forecasts expected:

And growth actually seems to be accelerating :

Usually you'd think this rapid growth would be a sign of “overheating” — that it would come at the expense of higher inflation. But while inflation is still a little elevated at around 3%, it's much lower than in other rich countries:

And thanks to the drop in inflation, real wages are recovering from their post-pandemic plunge. For the typical worker, hourly earnings are now pretty much back at the pre-pandemic trend:

As for why this is happening, and what could threaten it, that's a topic for a longer post. But right now we just need to realize that despite a two-year burst of inflation, the US economy has been doing really, really well since the pandemic.

3. China's real estate woes continue

A major economy that has not been doing really, really well since the pandemic is China. The basic pattern we all described two months ago — the inevitable crash of a bloated real estate sector, exacerbated by a dysfunctional local government financing system — is still in place. But it's useful to check back and see that things are still largely playing out as forecasted. Adam Tooze posted a great chart with a zoomed-out view:

And the New York Times has a good summary and update .

A week ago, Chinese property developer Country Garden indicated that it's going to default . This follows the pattern of Evergrande, which was the first domino to fall and is now facing liquidation . 《华尔街日报》 指出，许多投资者认为危机已经结束，他们可以低价买入中国房地产债券，结果发现这些债券的价值甚至比悲观主义者想象的还要低，结果却惨遭烧毁。 Meanwhile, it looks like a number of dominoes are still left to fall; Bloomberg's Shuli Ren writes about private equity companies that are set to take big losses from the real estate implosion.

But the biggest loser is likely to be local governments. These governments financed much of their expenditure with land sales for years, and now with the property sector crashing, that revenue has dried up. So they're largely surviving by borrowing. The problem is that no one wants to lend to the local governments , since they realize that the long real estate boom is probably never coming back, and thus the local governments are not going to have the money to pay back their loans.

So the central government is stepping in, telling state-controlled banks to keep lending money to the local governments at cheap interest rates. This is called “evergreening”, and it's what Japanese banks did with failed companies after the bust of 1989-91. It basically amounts to a bailout by the central government, but with one added negative characteristic. If their lending is directed toward local governments (which are basically non-productive borrowers), state-controlled banks won't be able to lend as much to the private sector, which could lower productivity and prolong the downturn — just like zombie lending did in Japan.

That said, China's government will certainly try very hard to push banks to lend to non-real-estate-related sectors. Here's an interesting chart posted by Bert Hofman showing a big burst of lending to industry:

China is going to try to replace the shattered real estate sector — which peaked at almost 30% of GDP — with a bunch of manufacturing. Time will tell how much of that manufacturing is actually anything people want to buy, or whether it's setting China up for a glut of overcapacity and waste.

4. Slavery wasn't just evil, it was bad for the economy

In the 2010s, it became fashionable to claim that the Industrial Revolution was enabled, or even caused, by American slavery. This idea served a number of rhetorical purposes, such as some socialists' desire to equate capitalism with slavery, or some progressives' urge to characterize everything about the American way of life as “stamped from the beginning” with the stain of slavery. This theory, which was part of the so-called “New History of Capitalism” and was largely promoted by historians rather than economists,

There was never a ton of evidence to back up this theory, but “not a ton” is not the same as “nothing”. One paper by actual economists estimated that the cheaper inputs from slavery did increase Britain's national income by 3.5% — not quite “started the industrial revolution” levels, but not nothing either.

But there's also a lot of evidence that slavery hurt the economy of the American South. A new paper by Richard Hornbeck and Trevon Logan describes why this was the case, and tries to quantify how much emancipation helped boost the economy. Here are some useful excerpts:

Characterizations of slavery as efficient and productive reflect the benefits and costs for slave owners, with market transactions oriented around extracting value from enslaved people. In this paper, we challenge this view. We re-characterize slavery as economically inefficient because there was a massive externality whose implications have been underexplored: enslavers considered their own private marginal benefits and private marginal costs of slave labor when making production decisions in the antebellum era, but they did not internalize the costs slavery imposed on enslaved people.当包括被奴役者本身所产生的成本时，奴隶制的巨大低效率就变得显而易见，因为奴役者获取的价值远远低于强加于被奴役者的成本。 Focusing on the cost of enslavement to the enslaved shows that slavery was a market failure in addition to a moral failure .

Since American slavery was economically inefficient, in this aggregate sense, emancipation generated substantial aggregate economic gains. While output declined after emancipation, input costs declined substantially more, which increased aggregate economic surplus: the total value of output minus total costs incurred…Emancipation reduced input costs that were not paid under slavery, due to coercion, but were still incurred by enslaved people and reduced aggregate surplus in the US economy…[W]e calculate that emancipation generated economic gains that exceed estimated costs of the Civil War…Emancipation generated aggregate economic gains worth 7 – 60 years of technological innovation in the 19th century[.]

The argument here is actually a subtle but powerful one. Because slavers basically got to ignore many of the costs they foisted on slaves, they made poor decisions about how to spend slaves' time and effort and skills — and the slaves were also forced to make bad decisions. As the authors write, “slavery was not only a substantial transfer of value from enslaved people to enslavers, it was also an inefficient mechanism of transferring value.”

(And as an aside, there are other, more complex distortions that this paper doesn't even take into account, like investment decisions . Because slavers faced the wrong prices for their investment decisions — slave labor was artificially cheap — the slave states over-invested in agriculture instead of manufacturing. Which is why when William T. Sherman showed up to kick their butts, helambasted them by saying “hardly a yard of cloth or pair of shoes can you make”. This was one reason the Union won so decisively.)

Hornbeck and Logan's result stands in contrast to the paper that found that slavery made Britain a little bit richer. Future research should focus on harmonizing the methodologies in these models — combining natural experiments from emancipation with the theory of externalities. But in any case, this is a blow to the idea that slavery was a boon for the overall economy.

Which doesn't mean, of course, that the modern American economy is free from the stain of slavery. It just means that that stain is probably making us poorer rather than richer. Extractive labor policies like low-paid prison labor , commonly used in the American South, under-invest in human capital and are probably thus inefficient, for many of the same reasons that Hornbeck and Logan cite. In addition to being a human rights violation, of course.

5. The platform is the enemy

This past week on the platform formerly known as Twitter has been a tough one. The Israel-Gaza war has propelled the discussion to a level of insanity beyond anything I've ever witnessed. Other long-time users are noticing the same:

Of course some of this is because of the inherent divisiveness of the Israel-Palestine issue itself. But many of us have been warning for years that social media, and Twitter in particular, inherently rewarded divisive, extremist discourse, and elevated the worst people. There was no shortage of social science research supporting this finding, but more evidence continues to pile up all the time.

For example, here's a new paper by Milli et al. about Twitter's recommendation algorithm, which finds that the algorithm shoves divisive content in users' faces that they would actually rather not see:

In a pre-registered randomized experiment, we found that, relative to a reverse-chronological baseline, Twitter's engagement-based ranking algorithm may amplify emotionally charged, out-group hostile content and contribute to affective polarization. Furthermore, we critically examine the claim that the algorithm shows users what they want to see, discovering that users do *not* prefer the political tweets selected by the algorithm.

But you don't need a fancy recommendation algorithm to elevate the worst people; a new paper by Mamakos and Finkel finds that Reddit does this as well:

Toxic people are especially likely to opt into discourse in partisan contexts…[W]e analyzed hundreds of millions of comments from over 6.3 million users and found robust evidence that: (1) the discourse of people whose behavior is especially toxic in partisan contexts is also especially toxic in non-partisan contexts (ie, people are not politics-only toxicity specialists); and (2) when considering only non-partisan contexts, the discourse of people who also comment in partisan contexts is more toxic than the discourse of people who do not. These effects were not driven by socialization processes whereby people overgeneralized toxic behavioral norms they had learned in partisan contexts.

This is not a causal study, and the effect is not incredibly strong, but it still shows that the tendency is there.

This doesn't mean I think these new social media technologies were a bad invention (though Twitter's algorithm certainly needs to be tweaked). It's hard to imagine a world without even as simple and rudimentary an online discussion platform as Reddit! But what it does mean is that our society needs to adapt to the presence of these technologies. We need to start realizing that we have another enemy besides our traditional political opponents, and that enemy is the social media platform where we we get our news. Social media has taught itself to exploit natural human tendencies toward enmity and division, monetizing hate for engagement and profit. It's a dark mirror to the worst parts of our souls, and it's up to us to find ways to resist.

1. Michael Lewis was too nice to SBF

Michael Lewis has always been one of my favorite authors; I can only wish I had his generational talent for entertaining readers entertained with lifelike characters and gripping stories even as he teaches them actual useful information. Liar's Poker was the quintessential story of the cynical, greedy turn in the US finance industry, while The Big Short was the best chronicle of the madness leading up to the 2008 crisis.

But Lewis is now taking a lot of heat for being the closest thing that Sam Bankman-Fried has to a defender in the financial press. I haven't read Lewis' SBF book yet, but in recent interviews, Lewis certainly says things about SBF that are less negative than anything else I've read. For example, talking to 60 Minutes , Lewis said that he doesn't believe that SBF knowingly stole his customers' money. And in a recent Time interview , he asserted that the money was lost due to SBF's “catastrophic sloppiness” rather than to deliberate malfeasance. When asked if SBF is a serial liar, Lewis hedges, calling him a “serial withholder” instead. When challenged to respond to criticisms that he got to close to the subject of his book, Lewis shot back:

This is what happens when you address a mob, is what it feels like…The anger seems, to me, to be like a separate force and part of American life right now, rather than something that's rational…Lord knows the very easy, lazy thing to do right now would be to throw Sam under every bus you could, and try to make him seem as bad as possible, because people respond to that. But it just wouldn't be true. It's not the character I knew. It's not the situation I knew…There's a long history of people getting in trouble for books that are right, and the books end up being extremely valuable...And in this case, again, it felt like there's a tribe waiting that were natively hostile to the truth of the story I experienced.

I don't have enough information to say Lewis is wrong here, but I expect when all is said and done, there will be solid evidence that SBF knowingly stole from his customers. In fact, I kind of doubt the standard story that SBF gave the money to his hedge fund and gambled it all away; I suspect he just embezzled most of it for himself, and still has most of it stashed in various places.

So my bet is that Michael Lewis is just being way way too nice to SBF here. But why? Lewis didn't hold back when criticizing the bond traders at Salomon Bros. or the creators of mortgage-backed CDOs; why would he lob such a softball at a guy whose finance empire was infinitely more scammy than those others?

Maybe Lewis did get too close to his subject, or maybe the magic spell of cynical “effective altruism” that SBF and his cronies used to get on so many people's good side. But I suspect that the deeper thing that's going on here is that SBF, like so many crypto barons, presented himself as an anti-financier — a good guy taking finance back from the cynical Wall Street banksters who hustled everyone in the 80s and 90s and blew up the world in the 00s. In other words, SBF set himself up to be the antithesis of everything that Michael Lewis spent his early career bashing, when in fact he was just a far scammier version of the same.

The truth about the finance industry, I think, is that it's been humbled significantly since the days of Liar's Poker and The Big Short . The Dodd-Frank reforms and the tight regulation of systemically important banks, along with the aftermath of 2008 itself, really did make it harder to engage in financial shenanigans. Finance still makes a ton of money, of course, but its profit as a share of the total has fallen from over 30% in the early 2000s to around 18% today — barely higher than it was in the early 1960s.

The old Wall Street “masters of the Universe” have been humbled, and we don't need the likes of SBF to rebel against them.

3. America isn't building enough, but we are building

I've repeatedly lambasted America for being the “ build-nothing country ”. Our lack of state capacity, our insane permitting system that allows NIMBYs to block everything, our complacent acceptance of cost overruns and delays, and other factors threaten to prevent us from building the green energy we need to decarbonize our economy and the high-tech factories we need to compete militarily with China. There are various factors that contributed to this problem, but the main villain, as usual, is NEPA, the law that lets people sue any project to force it to complete cumbersome paperwork:

Progress has proceeded in fits and starts. Tree clearing prompted objections from some neighbors. It's becoming every clearer that it's going to be very hard to revive US industry — or accomplish progressives' goal of decarbonization — without throwing NEPA under the bus.

But that said, America has thrown a lot of money at industrial policy, and it's not all going to cost overruns or legal challenges. Battery manufacturing is up by almost 40% in real terms since the Inflation Reduction Act was passed:

My hope is that America's initial struggles with industrial policy will cause us to course-correct, to find and eliminate the bottlenecks and roadblocks and inefficiencies, rather than to throw up our hands and retreat back to laissez-faire economics. If we can use the impetus of green industrial policy to reform laws like NEPA that block abundance on a wide variety of fronts, then so much the better.

4. Did shoplifting make Target close a bunch of stores?

Target made a big stir a few weeks ago when it announced that it was closing a bunch of stores because of excessive shoplifting. The cities where stores were closed include San Francisco, Oakland, New York City, Seattle, and Portland. The reports fed a growing anxiety that tolerance of property crime is hollowing out retail in America's progressive cities.

The blogger Judd Legum challenged Target's claims , however. Analyzing police data, Legum found that there were fewer reports of shoplifting at and around the stores that were closing, as compared with other Target stores in the same cities.

Legum concluded that Target had other reasons for closing the stores, and was using shoplifting as a convenient excuse.

But while that might be true, critics were quick to point out that Legum's data isn't really reliable. Areas with lots and lots of shoplifting probably tend to report it less . In addition to “reporting fatigue” from huge numbers of incidents, there's the fact that the stores that are closing tend to be in poorer neighborhoods, where police are less likely to care enough to respond to reports of petty crime. If the cops don't care, why even report?

So Legum's investigation should have also investigated the reliability of these reporting numbers. Data matters, but data quality also matters.

On top of that issue, there are at least two other reasons why Legum's conclusion might miss the mark. First, there's mitigation costs . Stores in high-shoplifting areas might put all their merchandise behind plastic cases and hire a bunch of security guards. That might prevent shoplifting, but at the cost of massively increased labor costs — security guard salaries, plus the fact that store employees are now required to assist customers with every purchase. If every store in an area is forced to resort to such costly measures, shoplifting might decline in the entire area, but the cost to some of the businesses might be ruinous.

Second, there's a store's ex ante profit margins to take into account. If a store in a poor area charges lower prices and makes lower margins, then it might not take as much shoplifting to force that store to close. In fact, shoplifting at other stores far away might even force a low-margin store in a poor neighborhood to close, simply by reducing the profitability of the entire company and forcing a round of cost-cutting that hit the stores in the poor areas first.

In other words, there are tons of limitations in the case Judd Legum is making here. He might be right, but there are a lot of things he didn't take into account, so I'm not sure we learned a lot from his data-gathering exercise.

5. More anecdotal evidence on market-rate housing construction

As you know, I love citing evidence that building market-rate housing lowers rents. I would also love citing evidence to the contrary, if it existed, but there's just not a lot of it — pretty much every careful scientific study and anecdotal urban experiment reiterates the conclusion that supply is effective in lowering rent.

First, we have a report from Jay Parsons , an economist who studies rental housing. He finds that in areas with lots housing supply, rents for mid-market apartments go down the most, even if it's high-end apartments that are mostly getting built. The reason is that when you build fancy luxury apartments, a lot of people from the mid-market move to those nicer, newer apartments, leaving a glut of supply that pushes rent down. This is pretty much exactly what I predicted in my post about “yuppie fishtanks”. When you build nice apartments for yuppies, they move into those nice apartments, and stop trying to outbid regular middle-class folks for the older mid-market units.

这里真正引人注目的是戈尔丁的方法论是多么广泛和不拘一格。她认为女性工人的理论是对市场需求做出反应的理性决策者，但她也考虑了文化规范、政治和思想的传播。她运用自​​然实验、调查研究和经济史。她创建了全新的数据集，揭示了自 19 世纪以来女性就业的趋势。这让她发现女性并不是最近第一次进入劳动力市场，而是重新进入劳动力市场。这是诺贝尔奖获得者提供的有用信息图：

这种综合的、折衷的方法很重要，因为女性在劳动力中角色变化的现象是一个非常复杂的现象，有很多变化的部分。这是经济中广泛的“结构性”转变的影响——从农业到制造业再到服务业的转变。扩大教育等政策变化影响了女性在工作场所的机会，避孕药和家用电器等技术创新影响了工作与家庭生活之间的权衡。有女权主义等社会运动和反歧视法等政治变革。所有这些事情同时发生，并且相互作用。

如果说戈尔丁的作品中有一个简单的故事的话，那就是影响女性经济状况的主要因素是工作场所和家庭之间的权衡。如果经济迫使人们选择其中之一，那么女性的工作就会变得更加困难。工业时代，工作意味着在远离家乡的工厂里长时间工作，家务劳动是一项繁重的苦差事，计划生育很困难，教育很少，而且家庭传承着性别角色分离的传统，这使得女性外出工作变得特别困难。出去并在市场上谋生。新的服务经济，以及上个世纪的所有新技术和文化创新，让人们在照顾家庭的同时仍然可以出去工作。因此，我们生活在一个性别更加平等的时代。

但“性别更加平等”并不意味着不平等已经被克服。戈尔丁最著名的论文之一是2010 年与卡茨和玛丽安·伯特兰 (Marianne Bertrand) 进行的一项研究，该研究发现，女性在抚养孩子和职业之间仍然面临着某种选择。在追踪一所顶级商学院 MBA 的职业生涯后，他们发现，母亲身份与职业中断和工作时间缩短有关，而这些因素在统计上可以解释大部分剩余的性别工资差距。关键是，女性在大多数家庭中都是“随叫随到的父母”，这要求她们有更灵活的工作安排，从而减少高权力的职业。

当我看到这项研究结果时，它立即提出了两种缩小剩余性别工资差距的方法。第一个是偏好的转变，让男性更加关心育儿问题。正如戈尔丁发现的那样，这些文化转变非常重要。但作为一名技术决定论者，我对一项新的创新更为乐观：远程工作。

戈尔丁在 2014 年的一篇论文中写道，推进性别平等的关键是让工作更加灵活：

但是，要实现劳动力市场的平等，“最后”一章必须包含哪些内容呢？答案可能会令人惊讶。解决方案并不（必然）涉及政府干预，也不需要让男性在家庭中承担更多责任（尽管这不会有什么坏处）。但这必须涉及劳动力市场的变化，特别是工作结构和薪酬的变化，以增强时间灵活性。如果企业没有动力去不成比例地奖励那些长时间工作和工作特定时间的个人，那么工资中的性别差距将会大大缩小，甚至可能完全消失。这种变化已经在技术、科学和健康等各个领域展开，但在企业、金融和法律领域并不那么明显。 （强调我的）

戈尔丁不太确定如何实现灵活的工作时间。但那是在 2014 年，在大流行之前，Zoom、Slack 和 Google Docs 在需要引发远程工作革命的时候结合在一起。就像节育或洗碗机一样，远程工作是一项似乎将持续存在的技术创新。随着时间的推移，随着公司学习如何围绕地理分布更广的异步团队重组其生产流程，从而实现盈利，其生产力优势变得越来越明显。

除了其他好处之外，戈尔丁的研究在我看来似乎暗示远程工作将成为职业女性的另一个福音。规范正在发生变化，但速度缓慢且困难重重。女性不必成为“随叫随到的父母”，但如果她们愿意，那么远程工作将使她们更容易做到这一点，同时仍然保住一份高权力的职业生涯。我认为那些想要改善性别平等的国家——我正在关注你们，日本和韩国！ ——应该努力鼓励远程工作。

无论如何，克劳迪娅·戈尔丁获得诺贝尔奖是当之无愧的。她展示了一种研究经济学的新方法——汇集大量不同的方法、理论和数据源来解决一个非常大、非常困难的问题。正如她所说，这就是经济学的侦探工作。

但戈尔丁的研究不仅仅在于了解过去；还在于了解过去。这是为了改变未来。直面性别不平等等社会问题是一种相当普遍的倾向——对这些问题大喊大叫、哀叹它们，然后上街游行。有时这很有效，有时则不然。戈尔丁表明，这种直接的方法可以通过一种冷静的智力方法来补充，这种方法试图在功能层面上理解社会问题。通过了解技术、供需和激励措施如何补充社会规范和法律等内容，我们可以提高按照自己的喜好重塑世界的能力。毕竟，知识就是力量。

巴勒斯坦的事业则不同。对于这种历史终结的倦怠来说，这是一个例外。这是真正明显的压迫，而不是一些手动挥手的理论。这是一场可以（在某种程度上）合理地描述为非殖民主义的解放斗争。以色列与美国的联盟使其似乎成为西方的一部分，这意味着西方左翼人士可以反对它。而且由于大多数主流进步人士本能地支持以色列的继续存在，这个问题让西方左翼人士将自己与中左翼建制派划清了界限。

因此，西方左派开始更加依赖巴勒斯坦事业，使其在他们的地缘政治观点中变得更加核心。当其他人都在争论乌克兰战争、与中国的紧张关系、缅甸的种族灭绝或其他什么问题时，对于西方左派来说，整天似乎都是巴勒斯坦问题。

（显然，我在这里所说的是广泛的概括，但要遵守所有常见的警告。）

因此，当他们选择的英雄——他们在其中投入了如此多道德声望的自由战士——出现在一场音乐会上，开始斩首狂欢儿童和亚洲工人，绑架奶奶，天知道还有什么，西方左翼分子应该做什么？在这种情况下，在不改变整个意识形态的情况下，你实际上只有两件事可以做——你要么告诉自己，你的团队的不人道行为以更高目标的名义是合理的，要么在街上与最好战的分子并肩前进，或者你撤退并呼吁双方避免杀害平民。左倾领导人选择了后者，但许多基层人士选择了前者。

到目前为止，我一直顽固地避免对以色列-巴勒斯坦冲突发表评论。这场冲突在美国和整个西方的情绪、意识形态和媒体关注度与其实际影响美国战略利益的程度远远不成比例。中东的全​​球重要性正在迅速下降，而美国已经明智地开始脱离该地区，因此我们对这场冲突的兴趣主要是人道主义性质的。尽管像以色列和哈马斯之间刚刚爆发的战争是残酷和肮脏的，但双方似乎都不太可能摧毁对方。暴力循环只会继续下去，伴随着西方媒体无休止的尖刻但无效的尖叫。

但我确实认为，尝试找出这场冲突的现实终点是有用的，即使这个终点不太可能很快到来。

人们试图设想的最后一个终点是以《奥斯陆协议》为代表的“两国解决方案”。除了在其目前国际公认边界内的以色列国之外，该计划还设想在西岸和加沙建立一个单一的巴勒斯坦国。每当哈马斯袭击以色列，或者出现有关以色列在约旦河西岸定居点的新故事时，人们就会宣称两国解决方案已经死亡：

它们是正确的，原因我稍后会阐述。两国解决方案已经失效一段时间了。但这些人可能想到的替代方案是一国解决方案，涵盖以色列、约旦河西岸和加沙。一些评论员实际上想要一个一国解决方案，而不是简单地利用言辞来推动以色列走向两国解决方案。有些人梦想建立一个多民族国家，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人作为一个国家的成员生活在一起。另一些人则梦想着种族清洗，即以色列人或巴勒斯坦人被赶出他们现在的土地，到别处居住。这两个梦想都是完全不现实的，原因我将在下面解释。

那么，除了当前不幸均衡的永恒存在之外，还有什么是现实的呢？我能想到的唯一答案就是三态解决方案。我的意思并不是说把约旦河西岸交给约旦，把加沙交给埃及，这是一个古老的想法，人们过去称之为“三国解决方案”，不幸的是，这个词仍然占据着维基百科的页面。约旦和埃及无意重新吞并巴勒斯坦土地，巴勒斯坦人也不愿被它们吞并。相反，我所说的“三国解决方案”是指三个国际公认的民族国家——在其目前公认的边界内的以色列国，以及两个独立的巴勒斯坦国，一个在加沙，另一个在约旦河西岸。

我通过观察当前情况并运用三个基本原则得出了这个结论：

  1. 大规模的种族清洗将被最小化。

  2. 以色列人和巴勒斯坦人不想共享一个国家。

  3. 不连续的状态是不可行的。

这些原则使我认为，对当地当前局势进行正式化，仅对领土控制和人口分布进行微小修改，是唯一可行的解​​决方案。不过，正如我将解释的那样，我所说的“坚持”并不意味着敌对行动将会结束，或者民族统一主义的主张将被放弃。

为什么一国解决方案行不通

“一国解决方案”基本上有两种愿景。这些都是：

  1. 以色列人被驱逐的巴勒斯坦国

  2. 巴勒斯坦人被驱逐的大以色列

  3. 以色列-巴勒斯坦多民族国家，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人生活在同一个国家，并认为自己是一个民族的一部分

首先，有对以色列人进行种族清洗并在以色列现有领土、约旦河西岸和加沙地带建立巴勒斯坦国的想法。当你看到“从河流到海洋”这个词时，那就是这个意思。这是哈马斯明确明确的目标，也是广大巴勒斯坦人的普遍立场：

在约旦河西岸、加沙和东耶路撒冷，不到 40% 的巴勒斯坦公众支持这一方案而不是一国方案。自 2018 年以来，对两国解决方案的支持稳步下降。

此外，大多数巴勒斯坦人认为，冲突不太可能出现两国解决方案。相反，他们中的大多数人表示，他们更愿意收回所有历史上的巴勒斯坦，包括 1967 年之前的以色列。阿拉伯人和犹太人享有平等权利的一国解决方案排在第二位。

最初的民意调查非常清楚地表明，这意味着对犹太人的种族清洗，而不是巴勒斯坦人的简单政治统治：

此外，更多的人否认犹太人与历史上巴勒斯坦的任何土地有任何联系或权利……第三种选择，实现“在所有土地上实现一国解决方案，其中阿拉伯人和犹太人将在一个国家享有平等的权利” “从河流到大海”的受欢迎程度已被证明远远落后于第三位[.]

这一种族清洗的目标得到了西方数量惊人的左派人士的支持，他们认为以色列人的死亡或被驱逐出该地区是正义的——这是他们认为的“定居者殖民化”的逆转。

这种态度的旧称是民族统一主义。

这个“解决方案”根本不是解决方案，而是大规模暴行——驱逐或屠杀数百万人。一些西方左派认为这一结果代表了正义，这是对西方左派的严厉控诉。而且，这种结果将公然违反国家主权原则；以色列得到国际承认，接受它从地图上消失将是对全球秩序的巨大打击。

无论如何，以色列人本身并不认为自己是恰好生活在中东的临时居民；他们认为自己是中东地区的临时居民。他们出生在以色列，这是他们的祖国，他们将竭尽全力反对大规模驱逐或灭绝，使用他们可以使用的所有武器（包括核武器）。美国等国家将支持这场斗争。

因此，对以色列进行种族清洗以建立一个单一的巴勒斯坦国，无论从道义上还是实际上都是不可能的。同样，以色列对约旦河西岸和加沙地带的巴勒斯坦人进行种族清洗的想法既不合理，也极不可能发生。

让我们继续讨论另一个“单一国家解决方案”。以色列-巴勒斯坦多民族国家的想法受到西方一些自由主义者的青睐。先例就是以色列本身，尽管存在普遍的种族歧视、不平等以及以色列作为一个“犹太国家”的正式身份，但犹太人和阿拉伯人作为一个民族和平地生活在一起。按照这种观点，约旦河西岸和（也许）加沙实际上已经是以色列国家的一部分，看似民族分离的东西实际上只是一个种族隔离政权。根据这种观点，实施一国解决方案所需要做的就是以色列结束其种族隔离政策，并给予巴勒斯坦人作为其所属国家公民的充分权利。

这是完全行不通的，因为双方都不希望这样。巴勒斯坦人不希望这样，正如上面的民意调查所证明的那样，民意调查显示，大多数人支持民族统一主义和种族清洗，而对拥有平等权利的共同民主国家的支持程度较低。以色列人不希望这样，因为他们知道这将导致他们企图进行种族清洗和/或种族灭绝，这将导致双方的血腥内战、重新分裂和种族清洗，类似于在1948年。

一个简单的事实是，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人已经互相争斗太久了，不可能很快成为一个共同国家的公民。我们可以希望情况并非如此，但希望不会实现。因此，任何形式的“一国解决方案”都是完全不可能的。无论西方左派、伊朗或社交媒体上的各种流氓如何怂恿巴勒斯坦民族统一主义者，这都不会发生。

为什么两国解决方案行不通

《奥斯陆协议》中规定的两国解决方案是行不通的，因为加沙和约旦河西岸不会成为一个国家的一部分。首先，也是最重要的是，它们是不连续的。不毗邻国家的历史记录非常糟糕，巴基斯坦和孟加拉国的命运就证明了这一点。当然，阿拉斯加是个例外，但阿拉斯加大部分都是空旷的荒野；我怀疑如果阿拉斯加人口变得更多，它会试图脱离。相比之下，加沙和约旦河西岸的人口大致相当，约为 200 万至 300 万。

考虑交通。与阿拉斯加或加里宁格勒甚至孟加拉国不同，西岸是内陆地区。加沙人和约旦河西岸的巴勒斯坦人要访问彼此的领土，就必须沿着一条以色列可以随时选择关闭的陆地走廊穿越以色列；这将彻底损害巴勒斯坦主权。巴勒斯坦国将受到以色列的摆布，因为以色列总是可以威胁将其一分为二。

更重要的是，政治控制是通过面对面的关系、社会服务、基础设施建设等在当地建立的。这意味着加沙和西岸自然会倾向于由两个不同的政治领导人控制。事实上，这正是已经发生的事情。哈马斯和法塔赫这两个拥有武装民兵的巴勒斯坦政党曾于 2007 年相互交战；前者盛行于加沙，后者盛行于西岸。

这意味着加沙和西岸只是一个“国家”的一部分，因为他们都认为自己是巴勒斯坦人，他们都梦想有一个统一的巴勒斯坦国，并且国际社会认为他们是一个民族的一部分。但在地理、经济、政治和军事上，它们已经是独立的实体。由于以色列不太可能从地图上消失，因此在任何可预见的“解决方案”中，它们都将仍然是独立的实体。

因此，两国解决方案实际上是不可能的，而且一直都是不可能的——不是因为以色列的行动或巴勒斯坦民族统一主义，而是因为加沙和西岸实际上不可能保持团结。

三态解决方案会是什么样子

三国解决方案就是我们可以笼统地称为“威斯特伐利亚”解决方案——将所有可用土地和人口划分为国际公认的民族国家，并具有充分的地方自决权。简而言之，每个人都可以继续生活在自己居住的地方，每个人都可以拥有自己的国家。

当然，我不是第一个提出这个想法的人——它太明显了。您可以阅读Kaveh Afrasiabi 、 Benjamin Kerstein 、 Jacob Savage等人撰写的有关它的文章。但这个想法并没有得到应有的关注或支持。

三国解决方案需要国际社会承认加沙和西岸为独立国家，并享受由此带来的所有好处。以色列对加沙边界、水域和领空的控制将被视为战争行为而不是占领——不是“种族隔离”，而是类似于任何其他军事封锁的封锁。如果加沙和以色列互相轰炸或袭击，这些将被视为边境战争，而不是警察行动或恐怖主义。

这场战争可能会持续很长时间，但可能不会永远持续下去。几十年来，事实证明，民族国家体系非常擅长通过国际压力和相互军事疲惫的结合来结束边境战争。正如乌克兰所展示的那样，军事技术正在转向防御，这一事实也意味着以色列和加沙最终都会有停止战斗的动机。

经济学将是另一个强大的激励因素。目前，由于海上贸易被切断，加沙无法积累财富。其人均 GDP 估计仅为 1257 美元，使其成为地球上最贫困的地方之一。如果黎巴嫩独立并能够进行海上贸易，这个数字无疑会猛增——黎巴嫩的人均GDP大约是这个数字的3倍。最容易发展的行业就是旅游业——加沙有很多美丽的海滩、大量的历史古迹等。未来它将成为土耳其、可能还有海湾国家和欧洲的投资目的地。

所有这一切都需要独立的加沙与以色列签署持久停战协议。这将给哈马斯领导层带来压力，要求其接受在一些巴勒斯坦人看来是令人羞辱的妥协方案。这不会迫使他们结束民族统一主义言论；他们可以而且会继续谈论“从河流到海洋”的巴勒斯坦，并宣布他们打算有一天摧毁以色列。但有一天不是今天。

出于两个原因，西岸向独立民族国家过渡将面临更加困难的时期。首先，它地处内陆，与海上贸易隔绝，经济发展受到一定影响。但更重要的是，由于以色列在过去几十年里对非法定居者运动的支持，约旦河西岸拥有约45 万以色列定居者。这意味着，如果西岸要成为一个独立国家，这些定居者将必须要么 A）作为该国家内的宗教少数群体生活，要么 B）搬迁。

显然，这些选择中的任何一个都会违反我上面概述的三个原则之一。巴勒斯坦人不太可能以平等的权利对待本国的犹太定居者，并且可能会出现部族间暴力和最终的内战，以色列支持定居者，哈马斯和伊朗支持巴勒斯坦人，双方都会发生暴行和种族清洗。另一方面，以色列定居者被迫离开定居点是种族清洗。因此，无论定居者发生什么，都将是一件坏事。以色列政府鼓励定居者运动的殖民主义行为注定不会有幸福的结局。现在的目标应该是以尽量减少悲剧的方式结束它。

悲剧性最小的解决方案可能是让大多数定居者迁移到以色列边境附近一些地理上较小的定居点，然后以色列吞并这些地区。这是一张地图，表明这是相当可行的：

这个解决方案会让很多人非常生气，因为它将巩固以色列的一些征服——重要的是包括东耶路撒冷。巴勒斯坦人不会容忍这一点——但是，正如民意调查显示，他们根本不容忍以色列的存在，所以那里不会有太大改变。与加沙问题一样，三国解决方案并不意味着巴勒斯坦方面民族统一主义言论的终结。

至于国际社会，他们可以承认约旦河西岸巴勒斯坦国的独立，但不承认以色列的领土征服。我们这样做的例子已经很多了——例如，我们承认俄罗斯和乌克兰，但我们不承认克里米亚是俄罗斯的一部分。因此，西岸定居点将成为一场“冻结冲突”，就像东欧和高加索地区的许多定居点一样。但“冻结”部分确实是关键——承认西岸是一个独立的民族国家，并与以色列停战，西岸将能够和平发展并享有安全。一些领土将会丢失，仇恨和民族统一主义不会消失，但“种族隔离”政权将完全消失。以色列将不再陷入永恒的占领，使其能够在更稳定的边界内更安全、更和平地发展。

这就是三态解决方案。这显然并不完美，并且会涉及大量的痛苦和愤怒，以及一些持续的暴力。但是，主权的、国际公认的、独立的民族国家的“威斯特伐利亚”体系是迄今为止为组织人民之间土地分配而设计的最佳体系，没有理由认为这不是以色列人和巴勒斯坦人的最佳选择以及。

换句话说，（几乎）每个人都应该继续生活在他们现在居住的地方，并拥有一个国家。

当然，更困难的问题是如何从这里到达那里。加沙和约旦河西岸的巴勒斯坦人不太可能简单地宣布他们目前控制的领土独立。以色列必须单方面撤军和定居者，并宣布约旦河西岸和加沙地带独立。这将使加沙人和约旦河西岸的巴勒斯坦人做出选择：要么正式承认并获得所有相关的经济和安全利益，要么避免承认以表明对民族统一主义的承诺。我敢打赌，他们会选择前者，尽管可能需要一段时间才能改变。无论如何，考虑到短期安全风险和以色列右翼对定居者运动的意识形态承诺，尚不清楚以色列如何有动力做这样的事情。

但在我看来，像这样的三国解决方案必须成为以色列/巴勒斯坦的长期结局，其他所有解决方案似乎都不太可行。如果你有更好的想法，不涉及大规模种族清洗或关于以色列人和巴勒斯坦人作为一个民族联合起来的不切实际的假设，我很想听听。
